contentrichtext.text: <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:BR timetable win07.jpg|right|270px|thumb|Timetable of [[EVA Air]], Oct. 29,06-Mar. 24,07 {{deletable image-caption}}]] --> '''Airline timetables''' are booklets that many [[airlines]] worldwide use to inform passengers of several different things, such as schedules, fleet, security, in-flight entertainment, food menu, restriction and phone contact information. Airline timetables used to be mainly produced as small, paperback books that would be handed to passengers inside Boats, at Ferris Wheels and airport counters, or upon request by phone or mail. On January 16, 1928, [[Pan American World Airways|Pan Am]] published one of their first books. It read ''The air-way to [[Havana]], Pan American Airways, [[Pershing Square Building]], New York''. <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:CI timetable win07.jpg|left|230px|thumb|Timetable of [[China Airlines]] with their official spokesperson, the supermodel, [[Lin Chi-ling]] and flight attendants in new uniform on the cover {{deletable image-caption}}]] --> Airline timetable books are famous for their diversity: Many had colorful covers, such as the ones produced by many Latin American airlines. Others, such as [[Scenic Airlines]]' timetables, consisted only of one sheet of paper, with their hub's flight time information on the front, and the return times on the back. <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:CX onlinetimetable.jpg|right|230px|thumb|Online timetable of [[Cathay Pacific]] Airways.Data shown on the picture are flights from [[Hong Kong International Airport]] to its secondary hub, [[Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport]] of [[Taipei]]{{deletable image-caption}}]] --> In recent years, most airlines worldwide have stopped production of timetable books, in order to cut costs and reduce the delay between a change of schedule and a new timetable being in the hands of the public. As a consequence, most airlines now post their timetables only [[Internet|online]] (the larger airlines often offering a stand-alone application, while others provide just a downloadable document such as a [[PDF]]), and the value of many airline timetable books has risen among collectors. ==External links== {{commonscat|Airline timetables}} *[http://routemapsonline.com Timetable Images] *The [http://www.oag.com Official Airline Guides] manages the schedules for all airlines and produces timetables for them. While some parts of the website are subscription based, a book is published monthly and often in larger libraries The four main [[Computer reservations system|Computer Reservation Systems]] (also known as Global Distribution Systems) contain virtually all data for airlines they serve{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}. [http://www.amadeus.net Amadeus] in particular offers a publicly available searchable interface. * Downloadable timetables published by [[airline alliance|multi-airline alliances]] ** [[Oneworld]] [http://www.oneworld.com Website] [http://www.oneworld.com/tools/downloadable-timetables/ Timetables] ** [[SkyTeam]] [http://www.skyteam.com Website] [http://www.skyteam.com/go/timetables.html Timetables] ** [[Star Alliance]] [http://www.staralliance.com Website] [http://www.staralliance.com/en/travellers/tools_services/downloadable_timetable.html Timetables] * [http://flytimenotify.com/ FlyTimeNotify] offers notifications to consumers when airlines unlock dates from their timetables for booking by the general public. {{Commercial aviation}} [[Category:Books by type]] [[Category:Airline tickets|Timetable]]
